subject: RE: [junit] Order of execution

messageBody:
> > There is no guarantee that they will run in the order of the test file and
> > you should not write your tests in a way that depends on this. You should
> > use the setUp and tearDown methods to properly setup each test.

> I know that this is the "pure doctrine". But what do you do, if you
> have a series of dependent test (some interaction between two systems)
> that need a defined protocoll and therefor a defined order?

What I do is to make it one big test. I'll still see if the whole
thing failed or not, and if it fails then the failure message and
the stack trace will help me to tell how far it got. You lose the
usual advantage of running ALL the tests because those bits after
the failing test don't get run, but if we ran those bits they wouldn't
be valid tests ANYWAY since they depend on the previous test
which failed!

Basically, a single test can be as big as you like, it's just the
unit of testing which is independent of all other tests. USUALLY
we make very short simple unit tests because we try hard to avoid
this kind of dependence, but your need for dependent tests is not
unheard of, it's simply to be avoided when possible.

-- Michael Chermside
